p.seg: BIENNIAL REPORT OF THE Adjutant General OF THE STATE OF NEBRASKA 1931 - 1932

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN January 1, 1933 From: The Adjutant. General of Nebraska. To: His Excellency. Charles W. Bryan. Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. Subject: Biennial Report of 1931 and 1932. 1. In compliance with requirements of Sections 1 to 5, Chapter 55, Article 1, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska 1929, the following Biennial Report for the calendar years 1931 and 1932 is respectfully submitted. The Nebraska National Guard occupies an. enviable pcsition in its standing in the National Guard of the United States and that steady improvement which has so richly rewarded the efforts of its personnel for years has never been more potent than during the period covered by this report. Each year training has materially improved in a logical and progressive manner, and notwithstanding the fact that many states allot much more money for use of the National Guard, I sincerely believe there is not a better organization in any State in the Union than has Nebraska at this time. 2. The community interest in our units and the assistance siven by committees' of Chambers of Commerce and by the citizenship as a whole has been most gratifying and most helpful and I feel that this support is well warranted for it has become known throughout the State that our training camps are absolutely clean and wholesome and the fear of young men acquiring any bad habits in the Nebraska National Guard is a thing of the past. - 3. Annual armory inspections are made by nfricers of the United States Army detailed for that purpose. The results of our last armory inspections evidenced the closest conformity to prescribed schedules and found our organizations as a whole very satisfactory. 4. As previously reported, the most discouraging proposition with which the units of the Nebraska National Guard have to contend is

RLTORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL the rental of armories. It is almrst impossible to rent suitable buildings and we conduct a continual fi<rht tn h' li the rentals dnwn; on the other hand, the government is very irsistent th"!. we have armories that afford adequate proteclion to government property and that have ample space for armory drills and training. It is realized that Nebraska is behind ninny of Ire other States that have State owned armories and tie State is frequently criticised by inspectors on this ncc unt Lut th uuh c-nstantly urged to do so, I have not been willing and am not new willing to submit an rrmory biilding program for vour c-hsidcati-in, as well as that of the Legislature, until conditions generally speaking have become nearer normal. 5. The results of the Armory Drill Training and the Field Train - ing for the nerird of this report have been very satisfactory. The reports of officers from the War Department assigned to make in - spections indicate that the slate of tiarri'-a of nil organizations has steadily improved and that cur National Guard of today is better fitted to serve tl^e State or Nation in the event of an emergency than ever before in its history. In connection with the armory drills it is [.■ratifying to note that the attendance is Letter than it has ever been I'.efore and that many of rur companies h- ve enlisted to full strength authorized by the War Department and have a waiting list of those anxious to join. 6. The following is a list of ibe Urited States Army Officers and Sergeants who are detailed by the \\ ar Department to the State of Nebraska for instructional r.urposcs, and in reporting the increased efficiency of our National Guard pre per eppreciation of all lhe elements concerned therein would be lacking were not the regular army instructors on duty with cur troors accorded due recognition for their fine services to us. They have all given us the finest of co - operation, the most understanding and sympathetic aid in our problems and. in general, every opportunity to make the most of their ef - ficiency and time. Major Laurence W. Young, Inf. DOL., Lincoln, Nebraska Major Emil H. Burgher, MC. DOL., Lincoln, Nebraska Captain Jack L. Meyer, QMC. DOL., Lincoln, Nebraska Captain Harold H. Elarth, Inf. DOL., Omaha, Nebraska Master Sgt. Lee R. G. Ward. Inf. DEML., Omaha, Nebraska Sergeant Emet G. Roach, Inf. DEML., Geiing. Nebraska Sergeant Hjalmar R. Strom, QMC. DEML., Lincoln, Nebraska

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL Sergeant Zack T. Scarborough, MC. DEML., Lincoln, Nebraska Sergeant Joel G. Gerard, Inf. DEML., Lincoln, Nebraska 7. In conclusion I wish to express my rir-precintion to the officers and enlisted men of the National Guard who have through their hearty cooperation, assisted in bringing the Kel rast-a National Guard to the nresent high state of efficiency and the personnel thereof to a much higher standard. I also desire to extend my appreciation to the dozens of Chambers of Commerce and to the thrusnnds of loyal cit - izens who have given us their moral support and thireby assisted in rhaking the Nebraska National Guard a bigger and better organization. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General. Nebraska. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA . ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 16, 1931 General Orders No. 2 1. In recognition of Memorial Day, Saturday, May 30, 1931, conse - crated to the brave soldiers who sacrificed their lives for the American Republic, the National Flag, will, in accordance with par. 2, sub-par. 11, Army Regulations 260-10, lie displayed on all Armories and all stations of the Nebraska National Guard at half-staff from sunrise until noon on that day. To assist Veteran organizations in the ob - servance of the day, C-'iuniniuling Officers of National Guard Organ - izations will place their respective commands at the disposal of local lepKesentatives of the Gtand Army of the Republic on that day. 2. Owing to the fact thi't credit for drill will be given for these exercises, no other report will be necessary. By order of the Governor: It J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN, Asst. Adjutant General Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 15, 1931 General Orders No. 3 1. Pursuant to authority contained in Training Authority No. 43-1, file MB-354.1 Nebraska-23, May 21, 1931, the State Staff and Stale-

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL Detachment, 134th Infantry, 35th Division Train QMC, and 110th Medi - cal Regiment will go into Camp of Instruction at the Government Rifle Range, Ashland, Nebr; ska August 3 to 17, 1931, inclusive, under com - mand of Brigadier General Herbert J, Paul, and upon completion of this tour of duty the above named organizations will return to their home stations. a. Company E and Howitzer Company, 134th Infantry, will leave their home stations August 2, 1931. Co. E will leave camp A r gust 16, 193L so as to arrive at their home station August 17, 1931. The Howitzer Company will Lave camp August 17, 1931, so as to arrive at their home station August 18, 1931. 2. A camp supply detachment, consisting of Major H. C. Stein and two enlisted men- of the State Detachment, will go into camp at the eailiest possible moment July 31, 1931, and will remain in ".amp August 18 and 19, 1931. 3. The following will report at the earliest possible moment August 1. 1931, taking the fiist train ayailable for that purpose: Stute Staff and State Detachment, consisting of one Major, QMC, one Cap - tain, QMC, one Crptain, Ord.. and nineteen enlisted men; Service De - tachment, Service Company, 134th Infantry, consisting of one Captain. S. O, one First Lieutenant and fourteen enlisted men; Headquarters Detachment. 35th Livision Train, consisting of one Second Lieutenant and six enlisted men; and Service Detachment, Service Company, 110th Medical Regiment, consisting of one Captain, S. O, and ten enlisted men. They will form an advance detachment for the purpose of pre - paring camp site and establishing camp for the reception of troops and will report to Major H. C. Stein August 1, 1931. The Commanding Officer of the 110th Medical Regiment will designate one Captain, MC, to accompany the advance detachment of his regiment and will see that he is provided with the necessary medical equipment to establish a camp infirmary. This Captain will remain in camp with the rear de - tachment August 18, 1931. 4. Upon arrival in camp August 1 1931, the Commanding Officer, Service Detachment, 134th Infantry, will establish mess for his Detach - ment, and the Commanding Officer, Service Detachment, 110th Medical Regiment, will immediately establish mess for the State Detachment, Headquarters Detachment, 35th Division Train, and his Detachment The officers in charge should see that at least one regular cook is in - cluded for each of these messes. Commanding Officers of the 134th Infantry, 35th Division Train and 110th Medical Regiment will see that equipment necessary ft r establishing commissaries is forwarded with advance detachments.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 5. A rear detachment consisting of one Major, QMC, one Captain, QMC, and one Captain, Ord, of the State Staff, and nineteen enlisted men of the State Detachment will remain in camp August 18, 1931, for the purpose of necessary detail incident to the departure of troops from camp. 6. Details as to transportation, train schedules, supplies, epuip - ment. etc, will be handled by circular letters from this office. 7. The Commanding Officer of the 110th Medical Regiment will see that all officers are physically examined in accordance with para - graph 4, NGR 27. He will designate such medical officers as are neces - sary to carry out the provisions of this paragraph; he will see that physical examination papers are turned in to him by August 10, 1931, and will furnish the Camp Adjutant with a list of those officers who have not been examined. 8. All enlisted men will he physically examined on the day of their arrival in camp and company and detachment commanders will cooperate with the medical department in seeing that all men are present and that their men are so examined. The following named officers are designated to make the examinations called for in this paragraph and will report to the Camp Commander at 9:00 A. M. on the morning of August 3. 1931, for instructions pertaining thereto: Major Earl B. Brooks, MC Major John R. Bennett, DC Captain Herbert M. Eisler, MC Captain James B. Anderson, MC Captain Floyd H. Kinyoun, MC Captain Wallace A. Gerrie, MC 9. Travel directed is necessary in the military service of the State. By order of the Governor: H. J. PAUL. The. Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN, Asst. Adjutant General. Nebraska.

18 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN January 4, 1932 General Orders No. 2 1. The Commander-in-Chief announces with profound sor - row the death of Second Lieutenant Raymond R. Sorensen, 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard. 2. Lieutenant Raymond R. Sorensen enlisted in Hq. Co, 2nd Bn, 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard, July 7, 1921. Appointed Pvt lcl. July 7, 1921. Appointed Corporal April 9, 1924. Honorably discharged July 6, 1924, expiration term of service. Reenlisted July 7, 1924, warrant as Corporal con - tinued on reenlistment Honorably discharged July 6, 1925, expiration term of service. Reenlisted July 18, 1925. Trans - ferred to Howitzer Company, 134th Infantry, April 1, 1926. Appointed Sergeant April 15,' 1926. Honorably discharged July 17, 1926, expiration term of service. Reenlisted July 18, 1926, warrant as Sergeant continued on reenlistment Honorably discharged July 17, 1927, expiration term of service. Reenlisted July 18, 1927, warrant as Sergeant continued on reenlistment. Honorably discharged July 17, 1928, expira - tion term of service. Reenlisted July 18, 1929, .warrant as Sergeant continued on reenlistment Appointed 1st Sergeant October 1, 1928. Honorably discharged July 17, 1929, expira - tion term of service, Reenlisted July 18, 1929, warrant as 1st Sergeant continued on reenlistment. Honorably discharged August 20, 1929, to accept commission. Commissioned Second Lieutenant, Infantry, August 21, 1929. Federally recognized August 22, 1929. Served to death, January 2, 1932.

19 . REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 3. Lieutenant Sorenscn's service has been most valuable to the National Guard of this State, having been an active supporter and a diligent worker since he enlisted in same and his services were recognized as outstanding when he was pro - moted . and commissioned. Lieutenant Sorensen's military career as well as his work in civilian life has been a splendid example for the young men of his command with whom he has been closely associated and he will long be remembered as one of the able and efficient officers of the Nebraska National Guard, the sympathy of which is extended to his family in '.his, their hour of sorrow. By order of the Governor: II. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN. Asst. Adjutant General. Nebraska.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN April 11, 1932 General Orders No. 3 1. The safety rules for small arms firing set out below are pub - lished for the information and .midance of all members of the National Guard, and will be enforced at home ranges as well as at camp when - ever any firing is being done. 2. All officers are hereby charged not to permit any man to fiie with any weapon until he has been instructed and examined in these general safely rules and in the special' lules pertaining to the weapon he is about to fire. 3. While men are waiting on the "ready line", or just prior to that time, they will be examined in these rules by a commissioned officer. 4. No man will be allowed to take his place on the firing line who has not in his personal possession, a copy of these rules. GENERAL SAFETY RULES a. Before firing is done on any range, the danger area will be ex - amined and all persons and livestock will be excluded therefrom. b. Range guards, properly instructed in their duties, will be posted in such a manner that all approaches to the danger area will be covered. c. Red danger flags and, when deemed necessary, warning signs will be displayed at appropriate points to warn persons that firing is going on. d. A red flag will be displayed from a prominent point on this range at all times during firing.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL e. Arrangements will he made to notify the general public in that. locality, at least 2-1 hours in advance, that firing with ball ammunition is to be done. f. Whenever any firearm is first taken in hand, it will be presumed to be loaded and cocked until a caicful examination has proved the contrary. g. Any officer or soldier who observes ary conditions which make firing dangerous will immediately con.niand or signal "cease firing". h. The command "ceape firing" given on the range will always be i.he**ed instantly and proper investigation as to its propriety will be in.-.do afterwards. i. Ball ammunition will be issued to the firer only after his arrival on the firing, line. j. No ball ammunition will he tal en from the firing line by firer. k. Men will remain on the filing line until ordered off by the offi - cer in charge of firing. 1. Upon completion if the firing of any order, each weapon used ivll be inspected! on an '"inhpection line' which will he established be - tween the firing line and the ready line. m. In case of a "miss-fire" or "jam", tie weapon will be held point - ing toward the target and without further movement until it has been examined by an officer. n. No firing will be done bef< re the command "commence firing" has been given or after the command "cease firing." has been given. o. . All weapons within 50 yards of the firing line will be kept with the- firing mechanism in the "open" position. n. No loud talking and no instruction of any kind, no classes or group, will he permitted within 50 yards of the firing line.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL q. Before a unit leaves the range, it will be assembled and in - spected by its commander to see that weapons are clean and that no man has any ball ammunition in his possession. Its commander will then report personally to the officer in charge of firing the results of his inspection, and request permission to leave the range. „ RIFLE a. Special care will be taken to avoid the following causes of acci - dents: (1) cartridges becoming hot from prolonged exposure to the direct rays of the sun, (2) dirt or other obstruction in the bore, (3) undue amount of oil in the bore and (4) badly fitting (loose) bolt b. Each man will fire his own rifle. c. At the completion of firing, sights will be laid and bolls will be left open. d. Rifles not in the hands of the men will be kept in racks. e. Shoulder and elbow pads will be used. The use of cotton in the ears will be encouraged. PISTOL a. Before any firing is begun, the detail will be formed in single rank and pistols will first be inspected for general condition, and then, at the command of the inspector, will be tested for (1) safety lock, (2) grip safety, (3) half-cock notch safety, and (4) action of disconnection. Any pistol failing in any of these tests will be tagged and removed from the vicinity of the firing line. | b. Only one man per target will be allowed on the firing line. c. No pistol will be loaded until the firer is on the firing line and the command "load" has been given. d. Pistols will be kept locked, after loading, until the command "ready" is given. e. Finger will not be placed in the trigger until pistol is pointing at the target

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL f. In. case of a "miss-fire" or "jam", the firer will first remove the magazine and then wait for orders from the officer in charge of firing. g. When on the firing line the firer will not turn his head or body to the side or rear without first removing the magazine and slide to the "open" position. h. Anyone picking up a pistol will always execute "unload" imme - diately. i. Except in the firing line when pistol is pointing at the target, a pistol in the hand will always be carried at "inspection pistol". AUTOMATIC RIFLE a. Magazine will not be inserted until firer is on the firing line. b. Except when on the firing line, bolt will be in the "forward" position and no magazine will be in the magazine opening. c. After firing, no man will leave the firing line until "b" has been done. MACHINE GUN Wooden safety I locks will be inserted in the breech before the com - mand "stand clear'' is given and will not be removed until a new fire order is given. 3-INCH MORTAR a. The mortar will not be fired at a rate exceeding 10 rounds per minute. b. Projectiles will not be assembled until ready to fire. c. Green cartridges only and practice shell MK.I only will be used. d. More than three (3) powder lings will never be used.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL e. In case of "n.iss-fire", the projectile will be removed only by an officer or a noncommissioned officer and- only after two minutes have elapsed. f. Record will be kept of all "duds" fired and at the conclusion of the firing for the day they will be collected carefully and buried suffi - ciently deep to preclude any danger. COMBAT AND FIELD EXERCISES a. When blank cartridges are used, no rifle will be fired at anyone within 50 yards. b. When ball ammunition is used, no men except those in the most advanced firing position, will be permitted to fire. c. When an advance is contemplated firing must cease, rifles must be unloaded and locked, before the advance begins. Men arriving at the new and most advanced firing position may open fire without waiting for those who are in the rear to come up. By order of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN. Asst. Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 18, 1932 General Orders No. 4

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 17, 1932 General Orders No. 5 1. In recognition of Memorial Day, Monday, May 30, 1932, conse - crated to the brave soldiers who sacrificed their lives for the American Republic, the National Flag will, in accordance with par. 2, sub-par. 11, AR 260-10, be displayed on all armories and all stations of the Nebraska National Guard at half-staff from sunrise until noon on that day. STEIN. Asst. Adjutant General. Nebraska.

28 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 28, 1932 General Orders No. 6 1. The Commander-in-Chief announces with profound sor - row the death of Captain Henning F. Elsasser, 134th Infantry, Nebraska National Guard. 2. Henning F. Elasser was born at Fremont, Nebraska, October 10, 1883. He enlisted in Company L, 1st Regt. Inf. Nebraska National Guard, June 20, 1903, at the age of 20 years by Baehr. Appointed Corporal June 20, 1905. Appointed Ser - geant October 2, 1905. Reenlisted as a Sergeant June 20, 1906. Honorably discharged to accept commission March 26, 1907. Commissioned Second Lieutenant March 27, 1907. Commissioned Captain December 8, 1910, to rank from January 13, 1908. Recommissioned Captain S. O. No. 9, AGO, 1911, for five years. Commissioned Major, Third Battalion, 4th Inf, May 20, 1915, to rank from April 23, 1915. Mexican Border Service un - der call of President, June 18, 1916. Mustered out January 15, 1917. Commissioned Lt. Colonel, 4th Infantry, March 3, 1917, to rank from March 1, 1917, 'g. O. No. 6, AGD, 1917. Called into Federal service under call of the President March 25, 1917. Drafted into Federal service August 5, 1917, as Lt. Colonel Infantry, from National Guard. Assigned to Infantry to dis - charge. Honorably discharged October 17, 1918. Commissioned Captain, Company L, 134th Infantry, NNG, May 5, 1923, S. O. No. 62, AGO-Neb. 1926. Federally recognized May 16, 1923. Commissioned Captain, Infantry, ORC, November 20, 1923. Prior service in ORC two years, one month and sixteen days. Captain, Infantry, ORC, March 22, 1927.

29 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL H^aMMnH^^HI^HMHMMHMMflHHHflBMHainflHaBQM«ka^H2aH3i^HEfiMDluS.^^^HH 3. Captain Elsasser's service has been. of most unusual value to the National Guard of this State he having been an active supporter and diligent worker in same for years pre - vious to the World War, when his regiment the 4th Nebraska National Guard, entered the World War and was later con - verted into the 127th Field' Artillery, with which he served with credit to himself and his comrades. After the World War he voluntarily reduced himself in rank and took over company L of the 134th' Nebraska National Guard, in an endeavor to bring it up to a higher state of efficiency, which he was ab - solutely successful in doing. Had Captain Elsasser lived for a very few week' longer he would have again started to climb up the military ladder, as he was next in line and would have been promoted to the grade of Major. 4. Captain Elsasser was commonly known among his friends as "Heine", a nickname which he has carried through life and which perhaps would have been dropped long ago had it not been for his many close and intimate friends that had known him for so many years. He was of a sunny disposition, always true and reliable, a very efficient officer, one that could be depended upon to do the right thing at the right time and he will long be remembered as one of the most able and efficient officers of the Nebraska National Guard, the sympathy of which is extended to his entire family in this, their hour of sorrow. By order of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, • Nebraska. OFFICIAL: H. C. STEIN, Asst. Adjutant General, Nebraska.

Nebraska. 1 Inch Chart STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN ** . ■ ' April 10, 1931 Circular Letter No. 2 Subject: Target Practice, Small Arms, 1931. To: Responsible Officers Concerned. 1. COURSES TO BE FIRED. The following courses only are authorized during the year 1931. For rifle practice: Course D, T. R. 150-10. For machine gun practice: Course B, T.R. 150-35. For pistol practice: Dismounted course.. T. R. 150-20. 2. RECORD PRACTICE. Rec-rd practice for rifles, machine guns and pistols will he fired during the 1931 field training period. Organizations will complete the preparatory exercises and instruction practice at their home ranges. No instruction practice except a limited number of sighting shots will be permitted during the field training period. 3. PREPARATORY INSTRUCTION AND PRACTICE. No man will be permitted to fire record practice with the rifle, pistol or mach - ine gun who has not completed the preparatory exercises prescribed in T. R. 150-5, 150-10, 150-35, and who has not fired sufficient instruc - tion practice to demonstrate his ability to apply the principles taught in the preparatory exercises.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 4. RECORDS OF PROGRESS OF INSTRUCTION. Marksmanship (Preparatory) forms to show the state of instruction of individuals before starting range practice, and in addition, score books for rifle instruction practice and score cards for rifle, pistol, and machine guns will be mailed to unit commanders on requisition. Regimental and company commanders will require that these be kept in the manner required by Training Regulations, and regimental commanders will require that these marksmanship records, certified by the company commander, be brought to camp and submitted to their respective regimental commanders not later' than August 4,. 1931. 5. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 1. 1931 Circular Letter No. 3 ' • Subject: Mother's Day. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, NNG. The second Sunday in May haying been dedicated to the mothers of our country as the day on which we should express the love and reverence we owe them, you are directed to bring to the attention of the members of your organization who may be separated from their mothers on May 10 the duty which they can fulfill and the pleasure they can give by writing home on Mother's Day. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL. The Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 15. 1931 Circular Letter No. 4 Subject: Annuel Encampment, Nebraska National Guard, 1931. To: All Unit Commanders and All Field and Staff Officers, NNG. 1. The dates of the annual encampment, 1931, having been set i. e, August 3 to 17, 1931, inclusive, no organization will be excused

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL from attendance except when it does not comply with the provisions of Section III, NGR 45. At this point you are cautioned as to the absolute necessity of making yourselves conversant with the above quoted section and citations contained therein as non-compliance therewith will cause forfeiture of- pay of company officers. 2. All units will be notified direct by the USP&DO as to the exact hour of departure from heme station, rations, handling of bag - gage, train schedules, transportation requests, hills of lading, making of vouchers, etc. 3. Company commanders are authorized to purchase subsistence for enlisted men not to exceed 40c per meal and will follow instructions received from the USP & DO pertaining thereto. 4. Travel Discipline. The senior line oiTicer will assume command of the train and see that travel discipline is maintained, i. e, no men on top of the cars or on platjform, men not permitted to get off trains at stations without orders, and men's personal appearance and conduct correct All officers will familiarize themselves with Chapter IX, Movement By Rail, Field Service Regulations, 1923. The commanding officer will make a thorough inspection of the train before troops en - train at home station and after they detrain at camp and report to the Camp Commander immediately upon arrival any defects or faults found with railroads transpoi ting troops. Each company and de - tachment commander upon arrival at detrs ining point will immedi - ately report to Transportation Officer with reference to baggage detail. 5. Travel Uniforms. Enlisted men will wear woolen O. D. shirts, cotton breeches, service hats with hat cords sewn on, issue leg gins and issue shoes. Officers will wear the uniform prescribed for them. Company commanders will not permit enlisted men to bring civilian clothing to camp this year as they will not be permitted to wear same on leave or otherwise during the fifteen day training period. 6. Equipment. Enlisted men will carry prescribed individual and special equipment and the contents of the pack as shown in Training Regulations 50-80 and 5'J-90. Extra blankets, clothing, shoes, toilet articles, etc, and the bed sack and mosquito bars will be taken by each individual as personal baggage in the barrack bag or foot locker. Company commanders shi.uld check each enlisted man to see that he

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL provides himself with extra underwear, socks, towels, toeth brush, paste, hand soap etc, and that he has extra issue clothing, i. e, cotton breeches, and O. D. shirt. Cotton blouses and new Melton Cloth uni - form will not be brought to camp. 7. Addition; 1 Equipment. Organizations should carry as excess baggage (freight) orgar.izati n equipment and cleaning materials. In - formation pertaining to saddles, saddle equipment, and harness will be furnished in a separate circular letter. No target material will be brought to camp as i - . will be furnished there. No canvas cots will be brought to camp. 8. Ordnance. All ammunition exceft cal. .22, long rifle, will be brought to camp and turned in to the USP&DO, securing memorandum receipt for same; all empty cartridges (brass) in packing boxes, aim - ing devices, arm racks and lockers sufficient for men in camp, rifles, bayonets., and pist- Is for same and all other ordnance with which the individual and companies are equipped. The Howitzer Company, 134th Infantry, will biing only sufficient ammunition to be used in the con - duct of its fire on the range. 9. Special Equipment All Signal, Medical, and Engineer property, including lister bags, is to be carried. 10. Records. All records and office supplies will be taken, i. e. Property Records Individual Eecrds. Stationary, Service Records, Morning Reports, all text books, all blank forms on hand, and Score Books. A list in quadruplicate rf all officers and men attending camp will be turned in immediately upon arrival in camp. A list in quad - ruplicate of all officers and men absent from camp, with a statement as to cause of such absence, will l.e turned in immediately upon ar - rival in camp. 11. Transportation on equipment brought to camp other than enumerated above, which becomes excess equipment, will have to be paid for by the unit commander bringing or permitting same to he brought (M. B. file 554.4 Gen-81, May 25, 1931, Subject: Transportation of Equipment for Field Training.) 12. Messes. .All company officers will mess with their organization. Every effort should be made to secure the best possible cooks and mess sergeants, cs a good mess is one of the most important things toward contentment and good morale of an organisation. The Commanding

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL Officer, 134th Infantry, and the Commanding Officer, 110th Medical Regiment, with the Commanding Officer, 35th Division Train, QMC, will establish officers' messes jf or the Field and Staff Officers of their own organizations and such officers of the State Staff and Instructors as may be assigned thereto for nuss purposes. Messes are to be oper - ating so as to serve lunch at noon. August 3, 1931. 13. Attention is invited to Nebraska Circular Letter No. 24, 1929, and company commanders are admonished that same must be strictly complied with. 14. Owing to the fact that a large warehouse hrs been constructed on the area set aside for the enlisted men's automobiles and that there is now no available space on the camp site for the parking of same and ithat entraining at home station, travel en rcute to camp, and detraining upon' arrival constitutes a part of the instruction pertaining to trans - portation of troups incident to field training, no enlisted men's cars will be permitted to be brought to camp this year. 15. In the movement of troops to and from camp in units and sub - units having same, two officers, one of which shall be the company commander, must accompany troops en rorte and will not be permitted to travel by privately owned motor vehicles. 16. TSach unit and sub-unit emm-nder will appoint a mail orderly who will get mail for his unit or sub-unit direct from the camp post office. The camp post office will sell stamps and mail orders, register letters, and conduct a general business such as is done by post offices over the country. 17. The attention of all unit and s lb-unit commanders is called to the necessity of knowing their men are physically fit before taking them to camp as the number of major operations in our camp must be reduced and the only operative cases that will be taken care of during camp will be for conditions that have not previously existed and have been brought about during camp and in line of duty. 18. Unit and sub-unit commanders will make sure that they are not bringing any venereal cases to camp and in case any are found on the physical examination that will be made on entering camp, they will be returned to their home station at their own expense, without pay or allowances, as they will not be permitted in camp; such men will also be required to refund both railroad fare and subsistence expended on them in bringing them to camp.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 19. Unit and sub-unit commanders will make every effort to ascer - tain that their men are physically lit befoie bringing them to camp and see that they do not come under the Lei ds mentioned above and will read this letter to their command at every armory drill between the time of its receipt and the time of entraining for camp. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 20, 1931 Circular Letter No. 7 Subject: Return of Strength as of June 30, 1931. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders. NNG. 1. We are called upon by the Chief, Militia Bureau, to submit a Return of Strength on the evening of June 30, 1931, therefore all unit and sub-unit commanders are requested to wire this office their strength Tuesday A. M, June 30, in order that we may compile same and for - ward to the Chief, Militia Bureau, that day. f 2. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 22, 1931 Circular Letter No. 8 Subject: Government Transportation Requests, Annual Encampment. 1931. To: Officer ResponsiLle for Same. 1. In accordance with par. 73-c, NGR 71, Government Transpor - tation Request No. WQ is inclosed herewith to cover rail - road transportation (tickets) for your Company and any field or staff officers of the NNG residing at your station to Ashland Nebraska, and return, which should be completed as follows, after the number of persons for whom transportation is required has been determined: a. Enter with pen. ink, or indelible pencil under the block, "Number of Persons", the total (aggregate) to be transported. . b. Opposite "Est. cost S " enter the TOTAL cost c. Signature of Responsible Officer, with title thereunder, on the lower right hand corner of the Request. d. Postal card report (WD MB No. 36) in quadruplicate will be completed as required thereon, one to be given to the first conductor if he requests it and the second to be turned in im - mediately upon arrival at camp to the USP&DO. The third and fourth copies will be used for the return movement, the third to be given to the first conductor if he requests it and the fourth copy to be mailed as indicated thereon, with any un - used tickets that yc.u may have. e. SERIAL NUMBER— See that ticket agents show on each ticket and on each coupon thereof the SERIAL NUMBER OF THE TRANSPORTATION REQUEST used in getting the ticket so

REPORT OF. THE ADJUTANT GENERAL that tickets and transportation requests can be checked against each other. f. Secure a sufficient number of single tickets (not more than ten) to enable delivery to the conductor of the exact amount of transportation required and for the remaining tickets secure a party ticket. (Par. 95, NOR 71.) 2. If. prior to the surrender of Transportation Request to the ticket agent, it be found necessary to alter entries made thereon, such changes will be fully explained over y ur signature and rank in the blank space under par. 2 of the instructions on the reverse thereof. Postal card reports required above mutt he absolutely correct,. showing the number of persons actually traveling as me'mbers of your party for the incoming and the return movements. 3. The responsible officer in tl is case is acting as transportation officer and as train quartermaster and CI cck Lists B and C are in - closed for his information and guidance. \v ith reference to Form WD MB 35, this letter contains the information called for therein. Any accomodations in excess of those authorized by regulation will be charged against the lesponsil.le officer. 4. In addition to the above, the conductor of each division of the railroad is required to make a report in duplicate of the troops car - ried, which will be verified by the ofiicer in charge of the company, and signed by both. The duplicate co ( .y of this report is to be given to the offcier in charge and will be sent by him to the Finance Officer, U. S. Army, Transportation Bianch, v> ashint.ton, D. C, and must com - pare with par. 1-d as to number of passengers. (Par. 2-b (3) Ch"ck List C.) By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL: H. C. Stein. Major. (See par. 11, Nebraska Circular Letter No. 4, 1931.) Check List D is inclosed for your informr.toin arid guidance. 5. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL OFFICIAL: H. C. Stein. Major, USP&DO. Nebraska. 4 Incls. Incl. 1, Original B L with memos and S. O. Incl. 2, 3 copies of Property List Incl. 3, Check List D Incl. 4.- Public Voucher STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 25, 1931 Circular Letter No. 10 Subject: Athletic Program. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders,. NNG. 1. The following Athletic Program, Which may be changed slightly if circumtances -require is publisned for the information and guidance of all concerned. 2. Each unit and sub-unit commander will give this program his personal attention. 3. PROGRAM. a. FIELD MEET. Saturday, Aug. 15 (after 9:30 A. M.), is re - served as the Camp Athletic Field Day. (1) All entries in athletic events scheduled for that period will be released from all other military duties and the athletic field will be cleared of troops prior to the above designated hour. (Field Training Directive 6 b (5) )

48 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL (2) Track. AU track events will be put on as in previous years and medals awarded for 1st, 2nd, and 3rd in each event. b. SWIMMING. (1) Swimming events will be put on as in previous years and medals awarded for 1st, 2nd, and 3rd in each event (2) The swimming pool may be used only when life guards are present and on duly at the pool. c. BOXING. (1) There will be competitition in each weight division and a medal awarded to the winner in each weight d. MASS ATHLETICS. (1) All enlisted men not employed during the afternoon period as provided in Sections 1 to 6 inclusive, Field Training Directive, will be assembled for physical training, athletics, recreational games and sports and training for athletics or military competitions during the period from 1:15 to 3:00 P. M. upon all clays except Aug. 3, 8, 9, 15, 16 and 17. (Field Training Directive 6 (7) ) (2) The above activities will be grouped as follows: games, and other sports requiring close supervision. Period from 1:15 to 2:00 P. M, mass athletics, group swimming, preparation for field meet, and similar activities. (Field Training Directive 6a (7) (a)) 4. GENERAL PROVISIONS. a. Each regimental and separate battalion commander will im - mediately upon arrival at camp designate a regimental or battalion athletic officer, who will immediately' report to the Camp Athletic Officer as his assistant in the supervision of the recreational and athletic activities of the camp. (Field Training Directive 6a (7)(c) ) b. At least one noncommissioned officer or qualified private in each company, or like unit, will be excused from school or other duties to have charge of the assembly and control of the men of his unit for the afternoon periods. .For that duty he will be under the direction and control of the regimental or battalion athletic officer. (Field Training Directive 6a (7) (d) )

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL c. The noncommissioned officers or o.u:lified privates detailed as provided 'in the above paragraph (b) will also be excused from school or other duties to attend the school of instruction in mass athletics in the morning of each day at an hour to be designated by the Camp Athletic Officer. <1. All officers detaile-1 as above and others assigned as Camp Athletic Instructors will be under the orders of the Camp Athletic Officer and will report to him for duty. (Field Training Directive 6a (7) (e) ) e. All unit and sub-unit commanders will prior to leaving their respective home 6tatiors have all men who will be entered in the boxing contests accurately weighed and immediately upon arrival al camp will deliver to the Carrp Athletic Officer a list of their respective entries together with a statement of their accurate weights. f. All unit and sub-unit commanders will prior to leaving their respective home stations prepare lists of their respective or - ganizations' entries in the field, track, and swimming events and immediately upon arri.al at camp will deliver said lists to the Camp Athletic Officer. f>. GENERAL'S TROPHY. a. Adjutrnt General Paul is p.eain offering a cup to the company showing the greatest activity and efficiency in athletics. J). Prints will be awarded to the various companies upon the fcllowr.ig basis: (1) Boxing Owing to. the difficulty that has been experienced in ar - ranging a card for the second' evening of Camp (Tuesday) it has been decided to avvrrct a greater number of points to the companies having entries in the boxing bouts upon that evening. Therefore, upun the first Tuesday evening, .25 points will be awarded for each entry at the ringside in condition to box, and 15 points wil be award for each . round that the bout goes. Upon all other evenings points will be awarded as follows: 10 points will be awarded for each- entry appearing Hi the ringside in condition to box. 10 points will be awarded for each round that the bout goes. An additional 15 points will be awarded to the winning entry in each bout

50 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 25 points will be awarded to each entry who enters the semi-final. 50 points will be awarded to the champion in each weight division. (2) Swimming. 25 points will be awarded for each 1st. 15 points will will be awarded for each 2nd. 10 points will be awarded for each 3rd. (3) Track. 25 points will be awarded for each 1st. 15 points will be awarded for each 2nd. 10 points will be awarded for each 3rd. (4) Mass Athletics. 200 points will be awarded to the company evidencing the greatest activity and efficiency in mass athletics. 100 points will be awarded to the company evidencing the second greatest activity and efficiency in mass athletics. 50 points will be awarded to the company evidencing the third greatest activity and efficiency in mass athletics. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL The Adjutant General, Nebraska.

STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN . t July 20, 1931 Circular Letter No. 12 Subject: Camp Attendance of State Employees Who are Members of the Nebraska National Guard. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, NNG.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL Governor Bryan has announced to this office that his policy of permitting State employees of all departments over which he has con - trol, who are members of the Nebraska National Guard, to attend the National Guard encampments without loss of pay or vacation time, will be continued. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN Julv 20. 1931 Circular Letter No. 13 Subject: Tent Houses for First Sergeants and Supply Sergeants. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, NNG. 1. There has been constructed in each company area a tent house for the use of the first sergeant and supply sergeant. The regular up - right pole will be used, placing same upon the floor for foundation. Under no circumstances will holes be cut in these floors. 2. A sixteen penny nail may be placed in each corner for the pur - pose of holding the guy rope, which is deemed all that is necessary. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN August 22. 1931 Circular Letter No. 14 Subject: Limitation of Armory Drills, Fiscal Year 1932. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, NNG. The following letter from the Chief, Militia Bureau, pertaining t» the above named subject is published for the information and guid - ance of all concerned: "The Secretary of War directs that you be informed that the number of drills to be held during the Fiscal Year 1932, will be limited as follows: (a) During the 1st and 2nd Quarteis (July 1 to December 31. 1931, inch), not to exceed 24 Federal pay drills. (b) During the 3rd Quarter (January 1 to March 31, 1932, inch), not to exceed 12 Federal pay drills in addition to any part of the 24 drills not held in the 1st and 2nd Quarteis. (c) During the 4th Quarter (April 1 to June 30, 1932, incl.) not to exceeel 12 Federal pay drills in adelition to any pari of the 36 drills not held timing the 1st, 2nd and 3rd Quarters. (d) In no event will the number of drills for which payment is made from Federal funds exceed eight (8) in any one month, or forty-eight (48) during the fiscal year for any organization of the National Guard. W. H. Waldroii, Colonel, Infantry, M. B. For and in the absence of the Chief, Militia Bureau." By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 01 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN ; September 4, 1931 Circular Lelter No. 15 Subject: Result of Ordnance Inspection at the Annual Encampment, 1931. To: All Unit .and Sub-unit Commanders, NNG. 1. The following extracts taken from the report of the Ordnance Officer who was in chnrpe of ordnance instruction at the annual en - campment of 1931 is published for the information and guitlance of ail concerned: "3. Ordnance material in the hands of units was inspected v\ith particular attention to the condition of the bore, and an elfort wrs made timing the time allotted to instruct individuals in the work necessary to increase the efficiency of firearms anel the practical application of cleaning and preserving material. During this inspection it was discovered that the principal de - fect in the rifles was a considerable deposit of carbon in approx - imately one-thiid of the length of the bore toward the muzzle. In general, the tvvo-thiids of the length of the bore from the breech entl was clean and- well cared for. It is thought that the carbon deposit mainly is a combination of oil, powler fouling lind dust which hi s been carbonized by the high temperatures in - cident to firing and being firmly packed by the passage of the bullet The fact thct only a portion of the rifle barrel appears well caret! for indicates that when rifles are being cleaned, the forward and backward motion of the patch is not being extended In the muzzle. 4. There appears some lack of understanding of the term "sweating" as some bores of all types of small arms were found rusty beneath the' thin coating of oil. Sweating may obtain from two causes, one by not entirely removing the products of com - bustion and the other by not thoroughly drying the piece before • iling. Careful cleaning and inspection of the bores of small arms should be maele at freeiuent intervals for not less than three days after firing, also after the use of water or ammonia solution, to

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL insure the removal of rll moisture before final oiling. In some cases it was found that these frequent inspections were bein - made but that the fpr.Hcation of a light film of oil in the bore after these inspections was bring neglected and due to the moist atmosphere, especially in camp, nst wr.uld immediately form. 5. During the inspection directions for the necessary minor repairs discovered were piven some of which are here noted: Several machine gun tripods, M1917. were found without name plates. Effort shruld be made to locate and replace these at the home stations. If unable to do so, replacements should be requisitioned, giving the number cf the tripod so that the name plate can be properly stamped. Some replacement of broken and missing parts on machine gun carts and nachine gun ammuni - tion carts was noted and the units directed to requisition and replace these at their home stations. Carts which are stored at Ashland will be repaired during the 1932 training period by mechanics from this office." 2. This office wishes to call attention to the discrepancies noted in the above extracts and urge that all company and detachment commanders take the necessary precautions to correct same. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN September 12, 1931 Circular Letter No. 16 Subject: Repair and Renovation of Clothing and Individual Equip - ment, and Maintenance of Organizational Equipment F Y 1932.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL To: All Responsible Officers. NNG. 1. Jf funds are required by your organization it is directed that you furnish this office, not later than October 15, 1931, separate esti - mates for the following: a. Repair and Renovation of Clothing and Individual Equip - ment b. Maintenance of Organizational Equipment 2. In no case will any ohlh>rti n be incurred until estimate called for above hr.s been approved by this office. 3. The authorizatio.li of funds for Repair and Renovation of Clothing and Individual Equipment is intended for articles where the enlisted men have been discharged and not for the purpose of clean - in!- clothing for active men. Pressing of the overcoats, uniforms and the shining of shoes will not be authorized. By direction of the Governor: II. .1. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Xebrr.ska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN September 17, 1931 Circular Letter No. 17 Subject: West Point Preliminary Competitive Examination, 1931, for the Nebraska National Guard. To: All Unit anil Sub-unit Commanders, NNG. 1. The annual preliminary examination for the selection of one enlisted man of the Nebraska Nati inal Guard to take the competitive examination for appointment to the United States Military Academy will take place at the Adjutant General's Office beginning November 2, 1931. at 9:00 A. M., and continuing through November 4.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 2. To be eligible for appointment from the National Guard, an applicant must be an enlisted man of a unit recognized by the Fetleral Government. He must, on the date of admission, July 1, 1932, have served as an enlisted man not less than one year, must be between the ages of 19 and 22 years and must not he less than 5 '4" in height. The age and service requirements are statutory and cannot be waived or modified, but it is not essential that the service be continuous so that former service in the Guard may be counted in determining an applicant's eligibility. A pamphlet setting forth the requirements for admission to the Military Academy will be sent upon request -. e> 3. The candidate, selecteel will be authorized by the War Depart - ment to report for the regular entrance examination, which is scheduled to be held beginning on or about March 1, 1932, and the appointment available on July 1, 1932, will be awarded to the qualified candidate in -the order of merit established at the examination, which is com - petitive among all National Guard candidates. 4. Previously applicants have presented themselves to take this examinaton who were in no way qualified and could not hope to pass the rigid examination given. It has been demonstrated that an.appli - cant should have had at least one year in college, in addition to a high school education. The examination will be written and will con - sist of an exhaustive examination in the following subjects: Elementary Algebra, to and including quadratics, Plane Geometry, English Gram - mar, United States and General History, and English Literature and Composition. 5. No State Funds are available for the payment of any part of the expenses of applicants taking this examination. i 6. A blank form to be used in making application to participate m the examination is inclosed. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General,

STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN November 19, 1931 Circular Letter No. 19 Subject: Limitation of Armory Drills, F. Y'. 1932. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, NNG. The following voluminous letter from the Chief, Militia Bureau, is published for the information and guidance of all concerned: "1. The President, through the Director of the Bureau of the Budget, has directed that no deficits be incurred in the Army appro - priations for the current fiscal' year.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 2. Due to increased attendance at the field training camps of the National Guard last summer it is estimated that there will be a deficiency in the funds availatla for the conduct of the June, 1932, camps amounting to S600.000.00 3. Likewise, due to ircrersEd attendance at armory drill, it is anticipated that there -.rill be a deficiency in Armory Drill Pay, 1932, amounting to approximately 8860,000.00. This es'limuto is based upon the attendance during the fiscal year 1931 ant' that for the months of the fiscal year 1932 which lave passed. 4. It is thus apnarent that the Militia Bureau is facing a deficit for the fiscal year 1932 of 31,460,000.00. Of this amount, it is esti - mated that approximately S30J, 000.00 can be made up through the process of the transfer of funds from othei orojects of the item "Arming, Equipping and Training the National Guard" under the 10% interchangeability clause. This leaves a balance of 81,160.000.00 to be provided otherwise. 5. As stated above, in recommending a budget for the Army for the fiscal year 1933, the Director of the Bureau of the Budget stated that no deficiency estimated for the fiscal year 1932 would be approved. In view of this announced policy, it now becomes mandatory for the Militia Bureau to finance its activities for the fiscal year 1932 within the limiting figure of the sum appropriated for that year, and to meet the contemplated deficit indicated above through administrative action. 6. After a thorough study of the situation, it has beeii decided that of the expedients available for meeting the contemplated deficit, a reduc'ibn in the number of armory drill periods is the most feasible and will work less hardship on the National Guard i.s a whole. 7. In accordance with the above decision, the Secretary of War has directed that the arpuiy drill periods for Ihe fiscal year 1932 be reduced from 18 to 43, and he has excused all units and organizations of the National Guard. from participation in live (5) of the armory drills authorized for the fiscal year 1932 by letter of the Militia Bureau dated August 12, 1931. 8. The Secretary of War directs that you be informed that the lumber of drills held during the remainder of the iisoal year 1932 ■ be limited as follows: a. During the 1st and 2nd quarters (July 1 to December 31, 1931, incl.) not to exceed twenty-three (23) Federal pay drills.. b. During the 3rd quarter (January 1 to March 31, 1932, incl.)

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL not to exceed ten (It)) Federal pay drills in addition to any part of the twenty-three (23) diilhs not held during the 1st and 2nd quarteis. c. During the 1th quarter (April 1 to .1 ne 30, 1932, incl.) not to exceed ten (10) Federal pay drills in addition to any part of the thirty-three (33) drills not held during the 1st, 2nd and 3rd quarters. d. In no event will the number of drills for which payment is made from Federal funds exceed eight (8) in any one month, or forty-three (-!3) during the fiscal year for any individual or organization of the National Guard. !». This letter supersedes Militia Bureau letter of August 12, 1931, on the above subject. 10.- It is hardly necessary to say that the War Department re - grets more than it can say the necessity for the action taken. The National Guard may be assured that everything- humanly possible has been done by the War Department in this connection, even to the extent of suggesting the transfer of funds from items for the support of the Regular Army to make up the National Guard deficit. The condition of the Treasury however, has definitely precluded any solu - tion of the problem involving the expenditure of additional funds. (SIGNED) W. II. Waldron, Colonel, Infantry, MB, For and in the absence of the Chief, Militia Bureau." By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL. The Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN December 11, 1931 Circular Letter No. 23 Subject: Audit of Company Council Books. 1931. To: All Officers Responsible for Same. 1. Company Council Books will be closed on December 31, 1931. in accordance with the following instructions: a. Council Book Q. M. C. 15. h. Company designation with words "State Fund" added on cover. c. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL d. Number all vouchers consecutively for the calendar year, regardless whether receipts or expenditures. e. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN December 30, 1931 Circular Letter No. 24 Subject: Appropriation for the Nationr.1 Guard, F. Y. 1933. To: All Officers of the Nebraska National Guard. 1. I am advised by the Executive Council of the National Guard Association of the mcst serious situation that has faced the National Guard since its reorganization following the World War. 2. Items in the b-dpel as presented and recommended to the Seventy-second Congress by the Director of the Bureau of the Budget provide sufficient funds for or ly forty-two (42) armory drills and for the attendance at the summer camrs of only seventy-five (75) per cent of the present strength of the National Guard. 3. It further provides, ."that for the fiscal year 1933 armory drills shall be restricted to such number os can be provided without exceeding the amounts available in this act for such drills". Also "that attendance at camps of instruction shall be so limited that the cost of such camps, together with other expenses under this item, can be met wilhin the amounts made available in this Act for such camps". 4. These restrictive clauses if enacted into law annul the pro - visions of Section 91 of the Nationrl Defense Act, which now prescribes the minimum training that shall be had. This affects the training and pay of every officer and enlisted man in the National Guard. 5: With the above in view you are requested to immediately write to your representative in Congress from your district, both House and Senate, telling them of just the effect this reduction will have on the National Guard of our State. 6. Also suggest that this information be given to your Chamber of Commerce and Civic Clubs that are interested in maintaining the present high standard of our Guard. This is in no way asking for an increase over the fiscal year 1932 appropriations made by Congress. It is simply asking that the same number be trained as was in the

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL F. Y. 1932. In fact the amount rsked for the fiscal year 1933 is some - what less than the cost of the Guard for the fiscal year 1932 due to reductions made in other budget items, accounted for by lower costs. 7. It is not believed cur members of Congress will allow our State Guard to be crippled in so vital a feature as training if they are made acquainted with the situation that now threatens and it is my opinion that letteis from their respective districts will be more effective than only one fiom this office. 8. Please give this your immediate attention. Bv direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL. The Adjutant General, Nebraska. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN February 10, 1932 Circular Letter No. 2 Subject: Small Arms Practice, 1932. To: Responsible Officers Concerned. 1. WHO WILL FIRE AND CURS' S TO BE FIRED. Subject to the amount of ammunition available, the provisions of Training Circular No. 4, MB 1931, as amended, will govern small arms practice of all units in this state. 2. RECORD FIRING DURING THE FIELD TRAINING PERIOD. Record practice eluring the iield training period will be permitted only for such men as have not' been able to complete this firing on their home ranges. All pieparalory exerc'ses. all small bore firing, all pre - liminary firing with service ammunition, and as much of the record tiring as possible, will be completed at home stations. No instruction practice, except a limited number of sighting shots, will be permitted those firing record during the field training period anil no man who lias not completed the preliminary instruction firing will be permittei! to fire record. 3. RECORDS AND REPORTS. Blank examination forms (for re - cording the state of progress in preliminary marksmanship). Individual Score Books, and scoie cards will be sent to r. 11 units without requisi - tion, as soon as possible. Score. cards and Report of Individual Class - ification in Arms (Form AGO 110) must he submitted to cover small bore firing and the regular record filing. These reports will be in the hands of the regimental or similar unit commander not later than 5 P. M., August 1, 1932. Expenditure of ammunition is based on these two reports. 4. AMMUNITION, TARGETS, AND SUPPLIES. Upon the written request of a regimental or similar unit commander, ammunition, targets, target material, and supplies will be shipped, without further requisi - tion, in the amounts available for such regiment or similar unit. All ammunition will be accounted for at the annual encampment by the submission of special expenditure forms (which will be obtained at camp from the office of the USP&DO) and by turning in the surplus

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL ammunition not so accounted for, to the Camp Ordnance Officer not later than noon. August 2, 1932. 5. . The cal. .30 hall ammunition allowances are based on the num - ber of men armed with the rifle, except that no cal. .30 ammunition is allowed for recruits or. other men who have not fired and qualified in tie small bore course, unless such men have previously qualified with the rifle. Under no consideration will recruits or unqualified personnel fire cal. .30 ball ammunition. Cal. .45 ball ammunition will not be allowed peisonnel who have qualiiied in either of the two preceding years. | ' 6. Nebraska Circular Letter No. 2, April 10, 1931, and letter from this office on "Small Arms Practice, 1931-1932", dated October 12, 1931, are rescinded effective this date. Ey direction of the G: vern~r: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. This office receives a great irany letters in connection with the loss or destruction of Arm ny drill pay checks and in order to avoid unnecessary correspondence in regard to these checks, it is re - quested the following instuctions he issued to the officers of the National Guard in your State. When a Government check is lost or destroyed, the Treasurer requires that the payee report the loss or destruction in writing over his own signature, payee's letter is to he sent to the disbuis - ing officer who issuctl the check. The signature of the payee en - ables The Treasurer to have on file for comparison a specimen of the payee's signature for determination of possible forgery if check should be presented for payment. When this office has received a letter reporting less or de - struction if check it will be forwarded to The Treasurer with a re-

Morton, Major, Finance Dept Finance Officer, U. S. A." By direction of the Governor: H..J. REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN May 12, 1932 Circular Letter No. 6 Subject: Athletic Program. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, NNG. 1. The following Athletic Program, which may be changed slightly if circumstances require, is published for the information and guidance of all concerned. »««•«••■«.« 2. Each unit and sub-unit commander will give this program his personal attention and will cooperate with the Camp Athletic Officer in all particulars to the end that the program may be most interesting entertaining, instructive, and beneficial to the enlisted men and of - 3. PROGRAM a. FIELD MEET. Saturday, August 13, after 9:30 AM is re - served as Athletic Field Day. (1) AH entries in athletic events scheduled for that period will be released from all other military duties and the athletic field will be cleared of troops prior to the above designated hour. (Field Training Program .1932. 4 c.) (2) Track. All track events will be put on as in previous years and medals awarded for 1st, 2nd, and 3rd in each event. b. SWIMMING. (1) Swimming events will be put on as in previous years and medals awarded for 1st, 2nd, and 3rd in each event.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL (2) The swimming pool may he used only when life guards are present and on duty at the pool. c. ALL UNIT AND SUB-UNIT COMMANDERS WILL PRIOR TO LEAVING THEIR RESPECTIVE HOME STATIONS HAVE ALL MEN WHO WILL BE ENTERED IN THE BOX - ING CONTESTS ACCURATELY WEIGHED AND IMMED - ATELY UPON ARRIVAL AT CAMP DELIVER TO THE CAMP ATHLETIC OFFICER A LIST OF THEIR RESPEC - TIVE ENTRIES TOGETHER WITH A STATEMENT OF THEIR ACCURATE WEIGHTS. d. ALL UNIT AND SUB-UNIT COMMANDERS WILL PRIOR TO LEAVING THEIR RESPECTIVE HOME STATIONS PREPARE LISTS OF THEIR RESPECTIVE ORGANIZA - ■ TIONS'. ENTRIES IN THE FIELD, TRACK, AND SWIM - MING EVENTS AND IMMEDIATELY UPON ARRIVAL AT CAMP DELIVER SAID LISTS TO. THE CAMP ATHLETIC OFFICER. 5. GENERAL'S TROPHY. a. Adjutant General Paul is again offering a cUp to the company showing the greatest activity and efficiency in athletics. b. Points will be awarded to the various companies upon the following basis: (1) Boxing. Owing to the difficulty that has been experienced in ar - ranging a card for the second evening of camp (Tues - day), it has been decided to award a greater number of points to the companies having entries in the boxing bouts upon that evening. Therefore, upon the first Tues - day evening, 25 points will be awarded for each entry al the ringside in condition to box, and 15 points will be awarded for each round that the bout goes. Upon all other evenings, points will be awarded as follows: 10 points will be awarded for each entry appearing at the ringside in condition to box. 10 points will be awarded for each round that the bout goes.

82 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL An additional 15 points will he awarded to the winning entry in each bout. 25 points will be awarded to each entry, who enters the semi-final. 50 points will he awarded to the champion in each weight division. (2) Swimming. 25 points will be awarded for each 1st. 15 points will be awarded for each 2nd. 10 points will be awarded for each 3rd. (3) Track. 25 points will be awarded for each 1st. 15 points will be awarded for each 2nd. 10 points will be awarded for each 3rd. (4) Mass Athletics. 250 points will be awarded to the company evidencing the greatest activity and efficiency in mass athletics. 200 points wiU be awarded to the company evidencing the second greatest activity and efficiency in mass athletics. \ 150 points will he awarded to the company evidencing the third greatest activity and efficiency in mass athletics. 100 points will be awarded to the company evidencing the fourth greatest activity and efficiency in mass '-■ athletics. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL. The Adjutant General, Nebraska.

REPORT OF. THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBR/ SKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 2, VJ32 Circular Letter No. 7 Subject: Disposition of Armory Drill Pay Checks applied on Prop - erty Shortage. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Comrr.andeis, NNG.. The following letter from the Chief, Militia Bureau, is published for the information and guidance of all concerned. "1. It has been noted that the provisions of paragraph 25 c NGR 59, are not liein^ followed with respect to forwarding checks for cancellation. 2. Where checks are not delivered to payees on account of prop - erty adjustments, they sh uld be forwarded promptly to the Adju - tant, General of the stale for transmittal to the Finance Oilicer with lequest for cancellation, as provided in the Regulations cited. The practice of holding checks until proceedings under paragraphs 19 and 20, NGR 75-7. are instituted and completed and then transmitting the checks with- the Di-oceetHtigs should be discontinued. This will avoid the possibility of loss and eliminate the enormous amount of clerical work involved in recording and caring for the checks in the various offices through which they pass. 3. The various operations where a shortage exists which was not discovered until the check was received, are as follows: a. The check- -not being properly deliverable to the payee — should be returned for cancellation. b. Proceedings should be instituted to determine the amount of the shortage under paragraph 10 or 11, NGR 75 — 7, de - pending on which paragraph is applicable. . c. Militia Bureau Form No. 18, Statement of Charges, should be .prepared to accompany a pay roll — which may he supplemental- -at the earliest practicable date, i. e., either

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL on approval of proceedings under paragraph 20 f, NGR 75-7, or upon notification that survey proceedings author - izing the shortage have been approved by the Secretary of War. d. Pay rolls should be submitted accompanied by the State - ment of Charges, in order that proper credit may be ob - tained. 4. In no case will either .-.hecks, Statements, of Charges (Militia Bureau Form 18), or supplemental pay rolls be forwarded to the Militia- Bureau with the reports of survey.
