J. PAUL. The Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 20, 1932 Circular Letter No. 8 Subject: Return of Strength as of June 30, 1932. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, NNG. 1. We are called upon by the Chief, Militia Bureau, to submit a Return of Strength on the evening of June 30, 1932, therefore all unit and sub-unit commanders are requested to wire this office their strength Thursday A. M., June 30, in order that we may compile same and forward to the Chief, Militia Bureau, that day.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 2. The following form of telegram, giving officers and enlisted men separately, shuld be used: "Co. A, three officers, sixty-three enlisted men. (Signed) Smith, Captain." By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL. The Adjutant General, - Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN June 21, 1932 Circular Letter . No. 9 Subject: War Records of National Guard Units. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders. NNG. .The following letter from the office of the Chief of the Militia Bureau is published for the information and guidance of aU concerned. Anyone having such documents or records as is described in basic communication may,- if they so desire, forward same to this office when they will be forwarded to the Adjutant General of the Army through the Chief, Militia Bureau. "1. The publication of the historically valuable documents pertaining to the military operations of the United States in the World War (as those of the Civil War were published) will be the most enduring memorial to those who took part therein. 2. Before the publication of these records can be under - taken, the existing gaps in the files of the Adjutant General of the Army must be filled. Many important documents are in the possession of organizations or individuals. As an illustration of how prevalent this condition may be, the records of the First Division in the possession of the Adjutant General filled nine filing cases; those collected from units and individuals filled ten more.

86 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 3. While most of the lecords pertaining t> National Guard units are now in the files of The Adjutant General, where they are available for examination by members of the Historical Sec - lion, it is probable that foinier members of these organizations still have in their possession many historically valuable records. These scattered documents should be assembled and consolidated with those now in the archives. 4. Even apart from the eiuestion of publication, it is in the interest of National Guard units that ihe'se documents be collect - ed in one place under expert care before they are lost or dam - aged, where complete files may be available f' r use even before - they can be sifted, organized and edited for ultimate publication. It may be pointed out that the program of public construction in Washington includes provision for a fire-proof Archives Building, which will probably be complete within two years, with proper arrangements to facilitate research. 5. The value to the National Guard of thus concentrating the organization records as a source of military history is very great Troops can gain from history an experience in warfare more varied than that- of any one individual or unit. This eource of instruction will become of increasing value as time goes on and those who have had actual combat experience are re - placed by those who have not Units will be able to draw illus - trations for tactical, training, or administrative lessons from their own pest, thus increasing esprit-de-corps. 6. The Militia Bureau, therefore, suggests that the adjutant general of each state shall collect these scattered records and forward them to the Chief of the Militia Bureau for- transmission to the Historical Section) Army War CoUege. In forwarding these documents such restrictions or instructions should be made as may be deemed advisable. 7. The Historical Section, Army War College, will select the historically valuable documents, index and collate them, and prepare copies for the. printer. 8. It is desired that correspondence on this subject be with or through the Militia Bureau for its information. The Bureau will be glad to cooperate iii any way in this important work.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL S7 (SIGNED) W. II. Waldron, Colonel, Inf., MB, For and in the absence of the Chief, Militia Bureau". By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 5, 1932 Circular Letter No. 10 Subject: Annual Encampment, Nebraska National Guard, 1932. To: All Unit Commanders and All Field and Staff Officers, NNG. 1. The dates of the annual encampment, 1932, having been bet, i. e., August 1 to 15, 1S132, inclusive, no organization will be excused from attending except when it does not comply with the provisions of Section 111', NGR 45. At this point you are cautioned as to the absolute necessity of making yourselves conversant with the above quoted section and citations contained theiein as non-compliance there - with will cause forfeiture of pay of company officers. 2. All units will be notified direct by the USP&DO as to train s-chedules, transportation requests, anel "bills of lading. 3. Company commanders are authorized to purchase subsistence for enlisted men iit not to exceed 40c per meal and will follow in - structions received from the USP&DO pertaining thereto. 4. Travel Discipline. The senior line officer will assume command of the train and see that travel discipline is maintained, i. e., no men on top of the cars or on platform, men not permitted to get off trains at stations without, orders, and men's personal appearance and conduct

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL correct. All officers will familiarize themselves with Chapter IX, Movements By Rail, Field Service Regulations, 1923. The commanding officer will make a thorough inspection of the train before troops entrain at home station, and after they detrain at camp, and report to the camp commander immediately upon arrival any defects or faults found with railroads transporting troops. Each company and detachment commander up n arrival at detraining point will immedi - ately report to Detraining Officer with reference to baggage detail. 5. Travel Uniform. Enlisted men will wear woolen O. D. shirts, cotton breeches, service hats with hat cords sewn on, issue leggins, and issue shoes. Officers will wear the uniform prescribed for them. Company commanders, will not permit enlisted men to bring civilian clothing to camp as they will not be permitted to wear same on leave or otherwise during the fifteen day training period. 6. Equipment. Enlisted men will carry prescribed individual and special equipment and the contents of the pack as shown in Training Regulations 50-80 and 50-90. Extra blankets, clothing, shoes, toilet articles, etc., and the bed sack and mosquito bars will be taken by each individual as personal baggage in the barrack bag or foot locker. Company commanders should check each enlisted man to see that he provides himself with extra underwear, socks, towels tooth brush, paste, hand soap, etc., and that he has extra issue clothing, i. e., cotton breeches and O. D. shirt. 7. Additional Equipment. Organizations should carry as excess baggage (freight) organization equipment and cleaning materials. In - formation pertaining to saddles, saddle equipment, and harness will be furnished in a separate circular letter. No target material or canvas cots will be brought to camp. 8. Ordnance. All ammunition except cal. .22, long rifle will be brought to camp and turned in to the USP&DO. .All empty cartridges (brass) in packing boxes, aiming devices, arm racks, and lockers suf - ficient for men in camp, rifles, bayonets, and pistols for same and all other ordnance with which the individual and companies are equipped will also be brought to camp. The Howitzer Company, 134th Infantry, will bring only sufficient ammunition to be used in the conduct of its fire on the range. Machine gun companies will leave the new mount for guns recently issued at home station as same will be furnished at camp. 9. Special Equipment, All Signal, Medical, and Engineer prop - erty, including lister bags, is to be carried.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 10. Records. All records and office supplies will be taken, i. e.. Property Records, Individual Recirds, Stationery, Service Records, Morning Reports, all text books, all blank forms on hand, and Score Books. A list in quadruplicate of all officers and men attending camp will be turned in immediately upon arrival in camp. A list in quad - mplicate of all officers antl men absent from camp, with a statement as to cause of such absence, will be turned in immediately upon ar - rival in camp. 11. Transportation on equipment brought to camp other than enumerated above, which becomes excess equipment, will have to be paid for by the Unit Commander bringing or permitting same to be brought. (M. B. file 544.4 Gen-81 May 25, 1931, Subject: Trans - portation of Equipment for Field Training.) 12. Messes. All Company Officers will mess with their organiza - tion. Every effort should be made to secuie the best possible cooks and Mess Sergeants, as a good mess is one of the most important things toward contentment and good morale of an organization. The Commanding Officer, 134th Infantry, and the Commanding Officer 110th Medical Regiment, with the Commanding Officer, 35th Division Train, QMC, will establish officeis' messes for the Field and Staff Officers of their own organizations and such officers of the State Staff and Instructors as may be assigned thereto for mess purposes. Messes are to be operating so as to serve lunch at noon, August 1, 1932. 13. Parking. The main road through camp and entrance thereto will be kept clear of traffic at aU times. No cars will be left standing or parked in the road. The cais of officers will be parked along the river bank against the dike back of their respective areas. Driving on or off the main highway through camp will not be permitted except at such places marked for such purpose. No motor transportation will be permitted in the enlisted men's camp area. Field, Staff, and Organ - ization Commanders only, will be i ermitted to bring private convey - ance to camp. Company or like orpanization commanders may detail one private to take their (company ce mmander's) car to camp and return same to home station. All other officers and men will be re - qired to travel with company on train. Any private conveyance brought to camp without special permission other than set out above will be immediately impounded and held during the field training period. Officers bringing automobiles to camp will present State registration certificates at Camp Headquarters and have same registered on day of arrival. 14. The attention of all unit and sub-unit commanders is called to the necessity of knowing their men' are physically fit before tak - ing thepi to camp as tne number of major operations in our camp

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL must be reduced and the only operative cases that will be taken care - of during camp will be for conditions that have not previously existed and have been brought about during camp and in line of duty. 15. Unit and sub-unit commanders will make sure that they are not bringing any venereal cases to camp and in case any are found on the physical examination that will be made on entering camp, they will be returned to their home station at their own expense, without pay or allowances, as they wiU not be permitted in camp; such men will also be required to refunel both railroad fare and subsistence ex - pended on them in bringing them to camp. 16. No companies, detachments, or tletails will be permitted in camp in advance of the time ordeied in. for the purpose of condition - ing kitchens, putting up tentage, or doing other routine work unless they have been designated by order or otherwise by this office. 17. Unit and sub-unit commanders will read this letter to their command at every armory drill between the time of its receipt and the time of entraining for camp. By direction of the Governor: H. J. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 28, 1932 Circular Letter No. 16 Subject: Fishing.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL To: AH Unit nnd Sub-unit. Crmmanders, NNG. 1. For all those interested it is announced that the old swimming nool on the south and west side of the main camp will be thrown open to the members of the National Guard for fishing this year. 2. An effort has been made to keep all fishermen away from this nool for the last three years and it should now be well stocked so as to afford some real sport for those who enjoy wielding the rod. If you are a fisherman come prepared to get your share of fish out of this pool. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN August 5. 1932 Circular Letter No. 17 Subject: Limitation of Armory Drills, Fiscal Year 1933. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, NNG. The following letter from the Chief, Militia Bureau, pertaining to the above named subject is published for the information and guidance of aU concerned: "The Secretary of War directs that you be informed that the number of drills to be held during the Fiscal Year 1933, will be limited as follows: (a) During the 1st and 2nd Quarters (July 1 to' December 31, 1932, inch), not to exceed 24 Federal Pay drills. (b) During the 3rd Quarter (January 1 to March 3, 1933, incl.), not to exceed 12 Federal pay drills in addition to any part of the 24

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL drills not held in the 1st and 2nd Quarters. (c) During the 4th Quarter (April 1 to June 30, 1933, inch), not to exceed 12 Federal pay drills in addition to any part of the 36 drills not held during the 1st, 2nd rind 3rd Quarters. (d) In no event will the number of drills for which payment is made from Federal funds exceed eight (8) in any one month, or forty-eight (48) during the fiscal year for any organization of the National Guard. (SIGNED) George E. Leach, Major General, Chief, Militia Eureau." By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. ■ -- . STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN August 22. 1932 Circular Letter No. 18 Subject: Seventh Corps Area N.R.A. Riile Matches to be Held at Fort Des Moines. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, NNG. The following communication from the Commanding General, Seventh Corps Area, is published for the information and guidance of all concerned: "The 7th Corps Area Rifle and Pistol Matches nf the National Rifle Association will be held at Fort Des Moines, Iowa, on September 3, 4, and 5. These matches are for the states of Minnesota, Iowa, Miss - ouri, Arkansas, North and South Dakota, Nebraska, and Kansas, and

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL for this year they take the place of the National Matches which are ordinarily held annually at Camp Ferry but for which Congress did not appropriate funds this year. The Matches are held under the jurisdiction of Major General Johnson Hacood, Commander cf the 7th Corps Area. Colonel Charles E. Stodter, Commandinc Officer at Fort Des Moines, and well known to all rifle shooters, will be executive officer. A large number rf the National Rifle Association Matches will he staged including the clastic Wimbledon Cup Match at 1000 yards, and Free Rifle Matches. 1*1 ere will be matches for military rifles at 2u\J to 1000 yards, small bcre matches at !S0 to 200 yards, and pistol and revolver matches. Winners will be awarded the N.R.A. medals and trophies, and a large percentage of the entrance fees is also distributed in the form of cash prizes. These matches are open to any citizen of the United States over the ar;e of 18 years, inducing all elements of the Army of the United States. Any citizen in fact can attend, but all must be members of the National Rifle Association. They can join the association at the matches. As Congress has n^t appreciated any funds for thia competi - tion all attending must do so at their own expense, and' must provide tneir own rifles, pistols and ammunition, but the expense will be small. All competitois will be provided with sleeping accomodations in tents including bedding witi.out charge and' splendid mess arrange - ments at cost will be provided. They should arrive at Fort Des Moines, Iowa, not later than 6:00 i J . M.< September 2. Programs containing full information can be had by addressing a postal to the Executive Officer, N.R.A. Matches, Fort Des Moines, Iowa. These matches will aifoid all who attend not only -an opportunity to compete in the important, interesting, and national matches which were formerly held at Lamp Perry, Ohio, but opportunity to meet fellow rifle and pistol shooters from all over the central portion of the United States. Friendships wil be formed and renewed, and there will be opportunity to meet many shooters of national reputation. These competitions form a purt of the plan of the Federal Government lor the promotion of skill in rifle shooting among our citizens, the National Rifle Association being the federally recognized body actively con - cerned in this work. A large attendance is anticipated." By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska.

RE1 CRT OF THE ADJUTANT GLNER/ L STATE OF NLBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERALS DEPARTMENT LINCOLN . September 12. 1932 Circular Letter No. 19 Subject: West Point Preliminary Ccmpalitive Examination, 1E32 f-r the Nebraska Nationrl Guard. To: All Unit and Su!)-unit Commanders NNG. 1. The annual preliminary examination for the selection of o-ie enlisted man of the Nebrrska National Guard to take the competitive examination for appointment to the Urited Stales Military Academy will take place at the Adjutant General's Office beginning Tuesday, November 1, 1932, at 9:00 A. M.. and continuing through November 3. 2. To be eligible for appointment from the National Guard, an applicant must be an enlisted man of a unit recognized by the Federal Government He must, on- the date of admission, July 1, 1933, have served as an enlisted man not less than one year, must be between the ages of 19 and 22 years, and must nrt be less than 5'4" in height The age and service requirements are statutory and cannot be waived or modified, but it is not essential that the service be continuous, so that former service in the Guard may be counted in determining an applicant's eligibility. A pamphlet setting forth the requirements for admission to the Military Academy will be sent upon request. 3. The candidate selected will, he authorized by the War De - partment to report for regular entrance examination, which is sched - uled to be held beginning on or alu-ut March 1 1933, and the appoint - ment available on July 1, 1933, will be awarded to the qualified can - didate in the order of merit established at the examination, which is competitive among all National Guard candidates. 4. Previously applicanls have presented themselves to take this examination who were in no way qualified and could not hope to pass the rigid examination given. It has been demonstrated that an applicant should have had at least one year in college, in addition to a high school education.. The examination will be written and will consist of an exhaustive examination in the fcllowing subjects: Ele - mentary Algebra, to and including quadratics. Plane Geometry, English

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL Grammar, United States and General History and English Literature and Composition. 5. No State Funds are available for the payment of any part of the expenses of applicants taking this examination, 6. A blank form to he used in making application to participate in the examination is inclosed. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. Incl. (1) Appl. blank STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN September 20, 1932 Circular Letter No. 20 Subject: Repair and Rem vaton of Clothing and Individual Equip - ment, and Maintenance of Organizational Equipment, F. Y. 1933. To: AU Responsible Officers, NNG. 1. If funds are required by your organization it is directed that you furnish this office, not later than October 20, 1932, separate itemr ized estimates (showing unit cost and totals) for the following: a. Repair and Renovation of Clothing and Individual Equip - ment. b. Maintenance of Organizational Equipment. 2. In no case will any obligation be incurred until estimate called for above has been approved by this office. Owing to financial con-

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL ditions with which you are conversant the amounts asked for must be kept down to actual requirements and necessities. 3. The authorization of funds for the Repair and Renovation of Clothing and Individual Equipment is intended for articles where the enlisted men have been discharged and not for the purpose of clean - ing clothing for active men. Pressing of overcoats and uniforms and the shining of shoes will not be authorized. By direction of the Governor; H. J. To: All Reporting Officers. NNG. 1. There are inclosed herewith blank efficiency reports to be made out for the year ending December 31, 1932, which should have your immediate attention.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 2. After giving a thorough study to instructions contained in NGR 20, par. 74, Changes 2, dated September 12, 1930, make out your reports and forward same without delay to the officer to whom directed. 3. The reports should reach this office before the expiration of the month. This is a small matter if given your immediate attention. Let us all get them in, in proper form and AT ONCE. By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska! STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL-S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN December 8, 1932 Circular Letter No. 23 Subject: Test of Tentative Infantry Drill Regulations. To: All Company and Detachment Commanders, NNG. 1. Pursuant to letter from Chief, Militia Bureau, copies of Tenta - tive Infantry Drill Regulations, 1932, have been furnished all National Guard Organizations which are drilled in close order infantry drill and upon receipt of this communication all such organizations will immediately adopt the Tentative Infantry Drill Regulations and make a thorough test of same until April 1. 1933, at' which time report and recommendations on same wiU be forwarded through channels to this office. 2. It is imperative that your report and recommendations reach this office as near April 1, 1933, as possible in order that same may be forwarded to the Corps Area Commander who must make his comments

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL and recommendations so thev will reach the Militia Buler.u not later than May 20, 1933. \JJ By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General. Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN December 12, 1932 Circular Letter No. 24 Subject: Audit of Company Council Books, 1932. To: All Officers Responsible for Same. 1. Company Council Books will be closed on December 31, 1932, in accordance with the following instructions: a. Council Book Q.M.C. 15. b. Company designation with words "State Fund" added on cover. c. The account will be based on the calendar year and will be posted only under '-Other Funds'' and in accordance with paragraphs 2, 3. 4, 5 and 6 of the instructions. (See also the model.) d. Number all vouchers consecutively for the calendar year, re - gardless of whether receipts or expenditures. e. Certificates for receipts and itemized invoices for expendi - tures are required for all transactions from January 1, 1932. f. In case the full page of the account will not carry the year's transactions, cut off bottom of page above words "Total re - ceipts and expenditures" and the top cf the next page "In

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL accordance with j.! funds," etc., under the word "year" and above "month"', and paste these pages together. g. Funds subject to check will require the bank statement of December 31, 1932. h. Certificate must be submitted as a voucher showing the of - ficers that messed with your company and the amounts. 2. From the audits in the past it is noted that resporsible officers in some cases do not post their books when the transaction occurs. This practice must stop and every transaction should be actually posted on the date that it occurs. The canteen dividend for 1932 must be picked up under this yeai's business. In cases where the Council Book has been filled and the last certificate has not been signed it will be neces - sary to send in the old and the new book. However, these books should be used until they are completely filled and they are good for a period of from five to ten. years. 3. These Council Books with vouchers will be sent immediately to Major H. C. Stein, USP&DO-Nebraska, who will audit and return same, making report to this office of any discrepancies found. By direction of the Governor: I H..J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT I LINCOLN December 14, 1932 Circular Letter No. 25 Subject: Preparation of Supplemental Pay Rolls. To: All Unit and Sub-Unit Commanders, NNG. The following communication from the Chief, Militia Bureau, is published for the information and guidance of all concerned:

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL "1. It has come to the attention of the. Militia Bureau that the General Accounting Office has disallowed payment of sup - plemental armory drill pay rolls for the reason that the supplement - al rolls contain entries which differed from those on the original rolls which were sworn to as being correct. 2. Request is made that all concerned with the preparation of supplemental pay rolls be cautioned to see that all data af - fecting an officer's or enlisted man's pay be entered opposite the name of the person concerned and such rolls verified by the affidavit of the officer commanding the organization in which he swears that "this pay roll is correct and has been pre - pared in accordance with the laws, regulations, and instructions governing the National Guard". 3. Supplemental pay rolls should also contain a full state - ment of Ihe actual reasons for the submission. (SIGNED) W. H. Waldron, Colonel, M. B. For and in the absence of the Chief, Militia Bureau." By direction of the Governor: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska.'
